data.value: DIALOGUE QUALITY ASSESSMENT CRITERIA:  1. COHERENCE & RELEVANCE (40% weight):    - Responses are logically connected to previous messages    - Each turn addresses the topic or question appropriately    - No contradictory or nonsensical responses    - Maintains conversational flow and context  2. COMPLETENESS & STRUCTURE (25% weight):    - Dialogue has clear beginning and natural progression    - Conversations feel complete, not abruptly cut off    - Proper turn-taking between participants    - No missing or truncated responses  3. LANGUAGE QUALITY (20% weight):    - Proper grammar, spelling, and punctuation    - Natural, human-like language (not robotic or template-heavy)    - Appropriate vocabulary and tone for the context    - Clear and understandable communication  4. ROLE CONSISTENCY (10% weight):    - Speakers maintain consistent roles throughout    - No role confusion or switching mid-conversation    - Appropriate expertise level for assigned roles  5. EDUCATIONAL/PRACTICAL VALUE (5% weight):    - Content is informative, helpful, or educational    - Provides value to potential training use cases    - Demonstrates good conversation patterns  CLASSIFICATION GUIDELINES: - EXCELLENT: Meets all criteria excellently, exemplary dialogue - GOOD: Meets most criteria well, minor issues only - FAIR: Meets basic criteria but has notable quality issues - POOR: Significant problems in multiple criteria areas - REJECT: Unusable due to major coherence, completion, or quality issues

COHERENCE & RELEVANCE (40% weight):    - Responses are logically connected to previous messages    - Each turn addresses the topic or question appropriately    - No contradictory or nonsensical responses    - Maintains conversational flow and context  2. COMPLETENESS & STRUCTURE (25% weight):    - Dialogue has clear beginning and natural progression    - Conversations feel complete, not abruptly cut off    - Proper turn-taking between participants    - No missing or truncated responses  3. LANGUAGE QUALITY (20% weight):    - Proper grammar, spelling, and punctuation    - Natural, human-like language (not robotic or template-heavy)    - Appropriate vocabulary and tone for the context    - Clear and understandable communication  4. ROLE CONSISTENCY (10% weight):    - Speakers maintain consistent roles throughout    - No role confusion or switching mid-conversation    - Appropriate expertise level for assigned roles  5. EDUCATIONAL/PRACTICAL VALUE (5% weight):    - Content is informative, helpful, or educational    - Provides value to potential training use cases    - Demonstrates good conversation patterns  CLASSIFICATION GUIDELINES: - EXCELLENT: Meets all criteria excellently, exemplary dialogue - GOOD: Meets most criteria well, minor issues only - FAIR: Meets basic criteria but has notable quality issues - POOR: Significant problems in multiple criteria areas - REJECT: Unusable due to major coherence, completion, or quality issues

data.value:
DIALOGUE QUALITY ASSESSMENT CRITERIA:

1. COHERENCE & RELEVANCE (40% weight):
   - Responses are logically connected to previous messages
   - Each turn addresses the topic or question appropriately
   - No contradictory or nonsensical responses
   - Maintains conversational flow and context

2. COMPLETENESS & STRUCTURE (25% weight):
   - Dialogue has clear beginning and natural progression
   - Conversations feel complete, not abruptly cut off
   - Proper turn-taking between participants
   - No missing or truncated responses

3. LANGUAGE QUALITY (20% weight):
   - Proper grammar, spelling, and punctuation
   - Natural, human-like language (not robotic or template-heavy)
   - Appropriate vocabulary and tone for the context
   - Clear and understandable communication

4. ROLE CONSISTENCY (10% weight):
   - Speakers maintain consistent roles throughout
   - No role confusion or switching mid-conversation
   - Appropriate expertise level for assigned roles

5. EDUCATIONAL/PRACTICAL VALUE (5% weight):
   - Content is informative, helpful, or educational
   - Provides value to potential training use cases
   - Demonstrates good conversation patterns

CLASSIFICATION GUIDELINES:
- EXCELLENT: Meets all criteria excellently, exemplary dialogue
- GOOD: Meets most criteria well, minor issues only
- FAIR: Meets basic criteria but has notable quality issues
- POOR: Significant problems in multiple criteria areas
- REJECT: Unusable due to major coherence, completion, or quality issues

DIALOGUE QUALITY ASSESSMENT CRITERIA:

1. COHERENCE & RELEVANCE (40% weight):
   - Responses are logically connected to previous messages
   - Each turn addresses the topic or question appropriately
   - No contradictory or nonsensical responses
   - Maintains conversational flow and context

2. COMPLETENESS & STRUCTURE (25% weight):
   - Dialogue has clear beginning and natural progression
   - Conversations feel complete, not abruptly cut off
   - Proper turn-taking between participants
   - No missing or truncated responses

3. LANGUAGE QUALITY (20% weight):
   - Proper grammar, spelling, and punctuation
   - Natural, human-like language (not robotic or template-heavy)
   - Appropriate vocabulary and tone for the context
   - Clear and understandable communication

4. ROLE CONSISTENCY (10% weight):
   - Speakers maintain consistent roles throughout
   - No role confusion or switching mid-conversation
   - Appropriate expertise level for assigned roles

5. EDUCATIONAL/PRACTICAL VALUE (5% weight):
   - Content is informative, helpful, or educational
   - Provides value to potential training use cases
   - Demonstrates good conversation patterns

CLASSIFICATION GUIDELINES:
- EXCELLENT: Meets all criteria excellently, exemplary dialogue
- GOOD: Meets most criteria well, minor issues only
- FAIR: Meets basic criteria but has notable quality issues
- POOR: Significant problems in multiple criteria areas
- REJECT: Unusable due to major coherence, completion, or quality issues
